Scalable Multi-Database Privacy-Preserving Record Linkage using Counting Bloom Filters

Dinusha Vatsalan â€ƒâ€ƒ Peter Christen â€ƒâ€ƒ and Erhard Rahmâ€ 



Research School of Computer Science, The Australian National University Canberra ACT 0200, Australia â€ UniversitaÂ¨Â¨a\ddot{\mbox{a}}t Leipzig, Institut fuÂ¨Â¨u\ddot{\mbox{u}}r Informatik, 04109, Leipzig, Germany {dinusha.vatsalan, peter.christen}@anu.edu.au,â€ rahm@informatik.uni-leipzig.de
Abstract

Privacy-preserving record linkage (PPRL) aims at integrating sensitive information from multiple disparate databases of different organizations. PPRL approaches are increasingly required in real-world application areas such as healthcare, national security, and business. Previous approaches have mostly focused on linking only two databases as well as the use of a dedicated linkage unit. Scaling PPRL to more databases (multi-party PPRL) is an open challenge since privacy threats as well as the computation and communication costs for record linkage increase significantly with the number of databases. We thus propose the use of a new encoding method of sensitive data based on Counting Bloom Filters (CBF) to improve privacy for multi-party PPRL. We also investigate optimizations to reduce communication and computation costs for CBF-based multi-party PPRL with and without the use of a dedicated linkage unit. Empirical evaluations conducted with real datasets show the viability of the proposed approaches and demonstrate their scalability, linkage quality, and privacy protection.

keywords:
Record linkage, similarity, privacy, multi-party, communication patterns, secure summation

1 Introduction

A wide range of real-world applications, including in healthcare, government services, crime and fraud detection, national security, and businesses, require person-related data from multiple sources held by different organizations to be integrated or linked. Integrated data can then be used for data mining and analytics to empower efficient and quality decision making with rich data. Integrating data helps improving the quality of data by identifying and resolving conflicts in data values, enriching data with additional detailed information, and dealing with missing valuesÂ [2].

The analysis and mining of data integrated across organizations can be used, for example, in health outbreak systems that allow the early detection of infectious diseases before they spread widely around a country or even worldwide. Such an application requires data to be integrated across several sources, including human health data, travel data, consumed drug data, and even animal health dataÂ [6]. A second contemporary motivating example is national security applications that integrate data from law enforcement agencies, Internet service providers, businesses, as well as financial institutions to enable the accurate identification of crime and fraud, or of terrorism suspectsÂ [25].

In the absence of unique entity identifiers in the databases that are to be linked, personal identifying attributes (such as names and addresses) need to be used for the linkage. Known as quasi-identifiers (QIDs)Â [41], such attribute values are in general assumed to be sufficiently well correlated with entities to allow accurate linkage. Using such personal information across different organizations, however, often leads to privacy and confidentiality concerns. This problem has been addressed through the development of â€˜privacy-preserving record linkageâ€™ (PPRL)Â [43] techniques. PPRL aims to conduct linkage using only masked (encoded) QIDs without requiring any sensitive or confidential information to be exchanged and revealed between the organizations involved in the linkage. Generally, masking is conducted on QIDs to transform the original values such that a specific functional relationship exists between the original and the masked valuesÂ [41]. While there have been many different approaches proposed for PPRL (as reviewed inÂ [43]), most work thus far has concentrated on linking records from only two sources (or parties). As the healthcare and national security examples described above show, linking data from several sources is however commonly required in practical applications.

The drawback of the small number of existing PPRL solutions that can link data from multiple parties is that either (1) they only support exact matching (which classifies sets of records as matches if their masked QIDs are exactly the same and as non-matches otherwise) [14, 17] or (2) they are applicable to QIDs of categorical data onlyÂ [12, 22]. However, in many PPRL applications QIDs of string data, such as names and addresses, are required. These QIDs often contain errors and variations which necessitates the use of approximate comparison functions (that are computationally expensive in terms of the number of comparisons) for comparing QIDs. In this paper, we tackle the multi-party PPRL problem by developing an efficient privacy-preserving approach for approximate matching of (masked) QIDs of string data from multiple records.

We propose the use of Counting Bloom Filter (CBF) encoding, which is a variation of Bloom filter (BF) encodingÂ [43], to enable efficient and approximate privacy-preserving linkage of multiple databases. BFs are bit vectors into which values are hash-mapped using hash functions (as we describe in SectionÂ 2.1). CBFs, on the other hand, are integer vectors that contain count values in each position. Multiple BFs can be summarized as a single CBF using the vector addition operation between BFs. Previous BF encoding-based PPRL approachesÂ [8, 33] suggest using a linkage unit (Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU), which is a dedicated external party that can perform linkage by comparing candidate record sets (masked into BFs) from all database owners and calculating their similarities to classify them as matches or non-matches. Our hypothesis is that, rather than sending BFs from all parties to a linkage unit (Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU) to calculate their similarity, a single CBF for each candidate record set generated over pğ‘p parties can be used to calculate their similarity, as illustrated in FigureÂ 1 (left for BFs and right for CBFs). Since CBFs contain only the summary information (count values) of multiple records in their positions rather than the actual individual bit values of a single record as in BFs, they provide increased privacy compared to BFs, as we discuss in SectionÂ 6. To the best of our knowledge, this privacy aspect of CBFs has so far not been utilized in PPRL.

An additional challenge with multi-party PPRL is that complexity increases significantly with multiple parties in terms of both computational efforts and communication volume. A basic approach would be to send all masked records from all pğ‘p parties to a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU that can calculate pair-wise similarities between masked records, which is of Oâ€‹(p2â‹…n2)ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘›2O(p^{2}\cdot n^{2}) complexity, where nğ‘›n is the size of databases assuming all databases are of equal size. However, identifying a matching set of records from all pğ‘p parties is not possible with such a basic pair-wise comparison approach. On the other hand, the number of naÃ¯ve (all-to-all) comparisons between records required across all pğ‘p databases (ğƒ1subscriptğƒ1\mathbf{D}_{1}, ğƒ2subscriptğƒ2\mathbf{D}_{2}, â‹¯â‹¯\cdots, ğƒpsubscriptğƒğ‘\mathbf{D}_{p}) is equal to the product of the size of the databases (i.e.Â nÃ—nÃ—â‹¯â€‹n=npğ‘›ğ‘›â‹¯ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›ğ‘n\times n\times\cdots n=n^{p}). Addressing this complexity challenge, two-step algorithms have been developed where in the first step a private indexing/blocking technique is used to reduce the number of candidate record sets from npsuperscriptğ‘›ğ‘n^{p} to bâ‹…np/bpâ‹…ğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘superscriptğ‘ğ‘b\cdot n^{p}/b^{p}, assuming bğ‘b blocks of equal size. In the second step only these candidate record pairs have to be compared and classifiedÂ [43]. Compared to the quadratic number of record pairs when linking only two databases (Oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2O(n^{2})), in multi-party PPRL the number of candidate record sets increases exponentially with the number of parties (Oâ€‹(np)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›ğ‘O(n^{p})), and thus using existing private blocking techniques would not sufficiently reduce the number of comparisons, as has been empirically studied in several recent approachesÂ [26, 27, 39].

FigureÂ 1 overviews the naÃ¯ve computation and communication of (masked) candidate record sets from multiple parties (p=4ğ‘4p=4) using a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU. Independent of the used masking function (BFs in the left figure and CBFs in the right figure) and the communication pattern (direct one-to-one communication between each party and the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU in the left figure and ring-based communication among the parties in the right figure, as will be described in SectionÂ 2), the naÃ¯ve approach results in exponential complexity. Efficient communication patterns and advanced filtering approaches for multi-party PPRL therefore need to be developed in order to reduce the potentially huge number of comparisons. Moreover, with multiple parties the privacy risk of collusion increases, where a sub-set of parties collude among them in order to learn about another partyâ€™s (or sub-set of partiesâ€™) private data. Both examples for the naÃ¯ve method described in FigureÂ 1 are highly susceptible to collusion.

In order to overcome these scalability and privacy challenges of multi-party PPRL, we introduce two efficient CBF-based communication patterns that either use a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU or operate symmetrically without a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU (where a trusted external party is not available to act as a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU). The proposed approaches can significantly reduce the number of comparisons required between records in contrast to the naÃ¯ve all-to-all comparisons, and thereby improve the scalability while also improving the privacy (reducing the likelihood of collusions) by arranging parties into several groups and by distributing computations among parties.

Contributions: Our contributions in this paper are: (1) a novel multi-party PPRL protocol based on CBFs and secure summation for efficient, approximate, and private linkage; (2) two variations of extended secure summation protocols for improved privacy against collusion among the data base owners: (a) homomorphic encryption-based and (b) salting-based (using random seed integers); (3) two efficient communication patterns (with and without a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU) for reducing the comparison space and risk of collusion between parties and thereby improving scalability and privacy, respectively, in multi-party PPRL; (4) an analysis of the protocol in terms of the three properties of PPRL: scalability (complexity), linkage quality, and privacy; and (5) an empirical evaluation and comparison of our protocol with two baseline approaches using large North Carolina Voter Registration (NCVR)Â [4] datasets.

Outline: In the following section we describe the preliminaries. In SectionÂ 3 we propose our protocol for multi-party PPRL based on CBFs and secure summation, where in SectionÂ 4 we we propose two extended secure summation protocols to improve privacy of our approach, and in SectionÂ 5 we introduce two efficient communication patterns to improve scalability and privacy. We analyze our protocol in terms of complexity, linkage quality, and privacy in SectionÂ 6, and in SectionÂ 7 we conduct an empirical study on the NCVR datasets to validate these analyses. We provide a review of related work in SectionÂ 8. Finally, we summarize and discuss future research directions in SectionÂ 9.

2 Preliminary concepts and building blocks

In this section, we define the problem of multi-party PPRL and explain how CBFs can be used for efficiently calculating similarities (approximate matching) of QID values between a set of multiple (two or more) records (held by different parties) in PPRL.

We assume pğ‘p database owners P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1}, P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2}, â‹¯â‹¯\cdots, Ppsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘P_{p} with their respective databases ğƒ1subscriptğƒ1\mathbf{D}_{1}, ğƒ2subscriptğƒ2\mathbf{D}_{2}, â‹¯â‹¯\cdots, ğƒpsubscriptğƒğ‘\mathbf{D}_{p} (containing sensitive or confidential identifying information) participate in the process under the honest-but-curious (HBC)Â [43]. In the HBC model, parties are assumed to follow the protocol without deviating or sending false information while being curious to learn about other partiesâ€™ data. However, the HBC model does not assume that the parties do not collude among them to learn about other partiesâ€™ dataÂ [19]. We quantify the risk of collusion in multi-party PPRL and the reduction of risk by our communication patterns in SectionÂ 6.2. We also assume a set of QID attributes Ağ´A, which will be used for the linkage, is common to all these databases. We formally define the problem of PPRL of multiple databases as follows.

Definition 2.1

Multi-party PPRL: Assume P1,â€¦,PpsubscriptP1â€¦subscriptPpP_{1},\ldots,P_{p} are the ppp owners (parties) of the databases ğƒ1,â€¦,ğƒpsubscriptğƒ1â€¦subscriptğƒp\mathbf{D}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{D}_{p}, respectively. They wish to determine which of their records R1,iâˆˆğƒ1subscriptR1isubscriptğƒ1R_{1,i}\in\mathbf{D}_{1}, R2,jâˆˆğƒ2subscriptR2jsubscriptğƒ2R_{2,j}\in\mathbf{D}_{2}, â€¦â€¦\ldots, Rp,kâˆˆğƒpsubscriptRpksubscriptğƒpR_{p,k}\in\mathbf{D}_{p} match based on the (masked) QIDs of these records according to a decision model C(R1,iC(R_{1,i},R2,jsubscriptR2jR_{2,j}, â€¦â€¦\ldots, Rp,k)R_{p,k}) that classifies record sets (R1,i(R_{1,i},R2,jsubscriptR2jR_{2,j}, â€¦â€¦\ldots, Rp,k)R_{p,k}) into one of the two classes ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M} of matches and ğ”ğ”\mathbf{U} of non-matches. Assuming the HBC adversary model, parties P1,â€¦,PpsubscriptP1â€¦subscriptPpP_{1},\ldots,P_{p} are honest, in that they follow the linkage protocol steps, while they do not wish to reveal their actual records R1,i,â€¦,Rp,ksubscriptR1iâ€¦subscriptRpk{R}_{1,i},\ldots,{R}_{p,k} with any other party. They however are prepared to disclose to each other, or to an external party, the actual values of some selected attributes of the record sets that are in class ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M} to allow analysis.

Masking functions used for privacy-preserving algorithms can be categorized into two: cryptographic-based secure multi-party computation (SMC) techniques and perturbation-based techniquesÂ [41]. The former approach is generally more expensive with regard to the computation and communication complexities though it provides strong privacy guarantees and high accuracyÂ [18]. The latter uses efficient techniques and, as opposed to SMC techniques, these techniques aim to hide (mask) information about the original values (to preserve privacy) while still allowing to perform approximate matching between the masked values using the functional relationship between original and masked data.

We propose an efficient protocol for multi-party PPRL using perturbation-based masking. In this section, we describe the four building blocks of our protocol, and in SectionÂ 3 we present our algorithm in detail. In the following two sections we assume a linkage unit (Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU) is available to conduct the linkage, and in SectionÂ 5 we propose a variation where a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU is not required to conduct the linkage using our protocol.

2.1 Bloom filter encoding

Bloom filter (BF) encoding has been used as an efficient masking (encoding) technique in several PPRL solutionsÂ [9, 17, 26, 34, 35, 38, 39, 40]. A BF bisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–b_{i} is a bit array data structure of length lğ‘™l bits where all bits are initially set to 00. kğ‘˜k independent hash functions, h1,h2,â€¦,hksubscriptâ„1subscriptâ„2â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘˜h_{1},h_{2},\ldots,h_{k}, each with range 1,â€¦â€‹l1â€¦ğ‘™1,\ldots l, are used to map each of the elements sğ‘ s in a set Sğ‘†S into the BF by setting the bit positions hjâ€‹(s)subscriptâ„ğ‘—ğ‘ h_{j}(s) with 1â‰¤jâ‰¤k1ğ‘—ğ‘˜1\leq j\leq k to 111.

Schnell et al.Â [34] were the first to propose a method for approximate matching in PPRL of two databases using BFs. In their work, as in our protocol, the character qğ‘q-grams (sub-strings of length qğ‘q) of QID values in Ağ´A of each record in the databases to be linked are hash-mapped into a BF using kğ‘˜k independent hash functions. This method of BF encoding is known as Cryptographic Long term Key (CLK) encodingÂ [34].

These BFs are then either sent to a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU that calculates the similarity of pairs of BFs, as suggested by Schnell et al.Â [34] and Durham et al.Â [9], or they are partially exchanged among the database owners to distributively calculate the similarities of BF pairs/sets, as proposed by Lai et al.Â [17] and Vatsalan and Christen for two-partyÂ [38] and multi-partyÂ [39, 40] approaches. FigureÂ 2(a) illustrates the encoding of bigrams (q=2ğ‘2q=2) of two QID values â€˜peterâ€™ and â€˜peteâ€™ into l=14ğ‘™14l=14 bits long BFs using k=2ğ‘˜2k=2 hash functions.

2.2 Dice coefficient

Any set-based similarity function (such as overlap, Jaccard, and Dice coefficient) can be used to calculate the similarity of pairs or sets of (multiple) BFs. The Dice coefficient has been used for matching of BFs since it is insensitive to many matching zeros (bit positions to which no qğ‘q-grams are hash-mapped) in long BFsÂ [34]. In future, we aim to investigate how other approximate string comparison functions, such as edit distanceÂ [30] and Jaro and WinklerÂ [10, 45], can be extended to calculate the similarity of more than two values.

We define the Dice coefficient similarity of pğ‘p BFs (b1,â‹¯,bpsubscriptğ‘1â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘b_{1},\cdots,b_{p}) as:

where zğ‘§z is the number of common bit positions that are set to 111 in all pğ‘p BFs (common 111-bits), and xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} is the number of bit positions set to 111 in bisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–b_{i} (111-bits), 1â‰¤iâ‰¤p1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leq i\leq p.

FigureÂ 2(a) illustrates the Dice coefficient similarity calculation of the two QID values â€˜peterâ€™ and â€˜peteâ€™ masked into BFs.

2.3 Secure summation

A secure summation protocolÂ [7] can be used to securely sum the input values of multiple parties (pâ‰¥3ğ‘3p\geq 3), such that no party learns the individual values of other parties, but only the summed value. The input can either be a single numeric value or a vector of numeric values. For example, pğ‘p numeric values (v1,v2,â‹¯,vpsubscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘£2â‹¯subscriptğ‘£ğ‘v_{1},v_{2},\cdots,v_{p}) can be securely summed by using a random numeric value râ€²superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²r^{\prime} which is sent by a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU. The first party P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} that receives râ€²superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²r^{\prime} calculates the summation of râ€²+v1superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²subscriptğ‘£1r^{\prime}+v_{1} and sends to P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2}. This process is repeated until the last party sends râ€²+v+1+v2+â‹¯+vpsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²ğ‘£1subscriptğ‘£2â‹¯subscriptğ‘£ğ‘r^{\prime}+v+1+v_{2}+\cdots+v_{p} to the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU which then subtracts râ€²superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²r^{\prime} from the summed value to calculate the summation of pğ‘p values. The protocol employs a ring-based communication pattern over all parties which allows the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU to learn the final values (âˆ‘i=1pvisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–\sum_{i=1}^{p}v_{i}) but no party will learn the values visubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–v_{i} of the other parties. This basic secure summation (BSS) protocol is susceptible to collusion risk among the parties. In SectionÂ 4 we propose extended secure summation protocols for improved privacy against collusion.

2.4 Counting Bloom filters (CBFs)

If the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU gets only the CBF cğ‘c that contains the summed values in the bit positions of pğ‘p BFs instead of the actual pğ‘p BFs, then the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU can calculate the Dice coefficient of pğ‘p BFs using Eq.Â (2.1) without learning any information about the individual bit positions of each party. As an example, the Dice coefficient calculation of the two BFs from the two parties P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} and P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} in FigureÂ 2(a) is extended by using a CBF and secure summation to calculate the similarity by the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU, as shown in FigureÂ 2(b). The information gained by the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU (and/or database owners) from a single CBF is less than pğ‘p BFs (i.e.Â CBFs provide increased privacy compared to BFs), as theoretically proven in SectionÂ 6.2 and empirically validated in SectionÂ 7.

3 Multi-party PPRL algorithm

Our protocol allows efficient, approximate, and private linking of records based on their masked QID values in multiple databases from pğ‘p (â‰¥2)absent2(\geq 2) sources/parties. We first describe a basic naÃ¯ve protocol based on CBFs, which we name as â€˜NAIâ€™, and in SectionÂ 5 we then propose improved communication patterns for this protocol to make it more scalable. The steps of our protocol are listed below.

  • â€¢

    Step 1:Â  The parties agree upon the following parameter values: the BF length lğ‘™l; the kğ‘˜k hashing functions h1,â€¦,hksubscriptâ„1â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘˜h_{1},\ldots,h_{k} to be used; the length (in characters) of grams qğ‘q; a minimum similarity threshold value stsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡s_{t} (0â‰¤stâ‰¤10subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡10\leq s_{t}\leq 1), above which a set of records is classified as a match; a private blocking function bâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹kâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘˜â‹…block(\cdot); the blocking keysÂ [2] BğµB used for blocking; and a set of QID attributes Ağ´A used for the linkage.

  • â€¢

    Step 2:Â  Each party Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} (1â‰¤iâ‰¤p1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leq i\leq p) individually applies a private blocking functionÂ [43] bâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹kâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘˜â‹…block(\cdot) to reduce the number of candidate sets of records ğ‚ğ‚\mathbf{C} (from âˆipnisuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–\prod_{i}^{p}n_{i}, where ni=|ğƒi|subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğƒğ‘–n_{i}=|\mathbf{D}_{i}| is the number of records in ğƒisubscriptğƒğ‘–\mathbf{D}_{i} held by party Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}), which otherwise becomes prohibitive even for moderate nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} and pğ‘p. The bâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹kâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘˜â‹…block(\cdot) function groups records according to their blocking key values (BKVs)Â [3] and only records with the same BKV (i.e. records in the same block) from different parties are then compared and classified using our protocol. A phonetic-based blockingÂ [2] or any of the existing multi-party blocking techniques for PPRLÂ [26, 27] can be used as the bâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹kâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘˜â‹…block(\cdot) function.

  • â€¢

    Step 3:Â  Each party Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} hash-maps the qğ‘q-gram values of QIDs Ağ´A of each of its nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} records in their respective databases ğƒisubscriptğƒğ‘–\mathbf{D}_{i} into nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} BFs (one BF per record in ğƒisubscriptğƒğ‘–\mathbf{D}_{i}) of length lğ‘™l using the hash functions h1,â€¦,hksubscriptâ„1â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘˜h_{1},\ldots,h_{k}. It is crucial to set the BF related parameters in an optimal way that balances all three properties of PPRL (complexity, quality, and privacy). We further discuss parameter setting for BFs used in our protocol in SectionÂ 6.

  • â€¢

    Step 4:Â  In the next step, the parties initiate a secure summation protocol to securely perform vector addition between their BFs in order to generate a CBF for each set of candidate records ğ‚ğ‚\mathbf{C}. This secure summation can be initiated by an external linkage unit Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU that provides a vector (of length lğ‘™l) of random values or by one of the parties (as will be discussed further in SectionÂ 5). This process is outlined in AlgorithmÂ 1.

    In linesÂ 3-6, the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU or the party that initiated the communication (we assume P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1}) sends or uses, respectively, a random vector ğ‘â€²â€‹[râ€‹eâ€‹c]superscriptğ‘â€²delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec] for each record râ€‹eâ€‹câˆˆğƒ1Mğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğƒ1ğ‘€rec\in\mathbf{D}_{1}^{M} to sum with the partyâ€™s BF vector biâˆˆğƒiMsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘€b_{i}\in\mathbf{D}_{i}^{M} (i=1ğ‘–1i=1) by applying a vector addition operation. This process is repeated until the last party (i.e.Â Ppsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘P_{p}) adds its bpsubscriptğ‘ğ‘b_{p} vector to each received summed vector ğ‘â€²â€‹[râ€‹eâ€‹c]+âˆ‘i=1pâˆ’1bisuperscriptğ‘â€²delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec]+\sum_{i=1}^{p-1}b_{i} from party Ppâˆ’1subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘1P_{p-1} and sends the final summed vector back to the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU or P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} for each candidate set câ€‹sğ‘ğ‘ cs, as shown in linesÂ 8-17 in AlgorithmÂ 1.

    Step 5:Â  Finally, either the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU or the first party, P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1}, that has provided the random vectors ğ‘â€²superscriptğ‘â€²\mathbf{R^{\prime}}, subtracts ğ‘â€²â€‹[râ€‹eâ€‹c]superscriptğ‘â€²delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec] from the final summed vector ğ‘â€²â€‹[râ€‹eâ€‹c]+âˆ‘i=1pbisuperscriptğ‘â€²delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec]+\sum_{i=1}^{p}b_{i} as received from the last party Ppsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘P_{p} for each candidate set câ€‹sâˆˆğ‚ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‚cs\in\mathbf{C}. This is achieved by subtraction of vectors (i.e. c=ğ‘â€²â€‹[râ€‹eâ€‹c]+âˆ‘i=1pbiâˆ’ğ‘â€²â€‹[râ€‹eâ€‹c]ğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptğ‘â€²delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘c=\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec]+\sum_{i=1}^{p}b_{i}-\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec]), which is a special case of vector addition, as outlined in linesÂ 2-4 in AlgorithmÂ 2. As shown in linesÂ 5-7, the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU or P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} then calculates the Dice coefficient similarity of each resulting CBF cğ‘c following Eq.Â (2.1) to classify the compared sets of records (BFs) within a block into matches and non-matches based on the similarity threshold stsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡s_{t}. The final similarities of matching sets of records will be sent to all parties Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}, with 1â‰¤iâ‰¤p1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leq i\leq p, in linesÂ 8-9 in AlgorithmÂ 2.

The basic secure summation protocol (BSS) used in this â€™NAIâ€™ protocol is vulnerable to collusion risk among the parties. Further, the number of candidate sets to be compared for multi-party linkage in this naÃ¯ve method (NAI) is exponential in the number of parties and their dataset sizes, which is prohibitively large to be practically feasible (even with the existing private blocking and filtering approaches employed)Â [39]. Efficient communication patterns among the parties therefore need to be employed in order to make multi-party PPRL scalable and viable in real applications that require data of very large sizes from many parties to be integrated. In the following sections we propose extended secure summation protocols and two efficient communication patterns that not only improve the scalability of our multi-party PPRL protocol but also make it more secure (with less possible collusion among the parties).

4 Extended secure summation

The basic secure summation protocol (BSS) described in SectionÂ 2.3 is susceptible to collusion risk by the parties involved, where if two or more parties collude they are able to infer the input of another party. In order to overcome this risk (to improve privacy), we propose two extended secure summation protocols.

  • â€¢

    Homomorphic-based secure summation (HSS): The partially homomorphic Paillier cryptosystemÂ [24] is a reliable secure multi-party computation (SMC) technique for performing secure joint computation among several parties. In the HSS approach a pair of private and public keys is used for encrypting and decrypting the individual BF values. Successive encryption of the same value using the same public key generates different encrypted values with high probability, and decrypting the encrypted values using a private key returns the correct original value. The public key is known to all parties while the private key is known only to the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU. Each party Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} receives summed vectors containing encrypted values to which Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} adds its encrypted ğ›isubscriptğ›ğ‘–\mathbf{b}_{i} vector (using the public key) and sends the encrypted summed vectors to the next party. Without knowing the private key a party Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} cannot decrypt the received vectors and therefore colluding with a party to learn another partyâ€™s ğ›jsubscriptğ›ğ‘—\mathbf{b}_{j} (with iâ‰ jğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq j) would be impossible.

  • â€¢

    Salting-based (using random seed integers) secure summation (SSS): The HSS approach provides a secure solution compared to the BSS approach against collusion attacks at the cost of an excessive computation overhead, making it not scalable to linking multiple large databases. Therefore, we propose the SSS approach to provide security against collusion attacks in an efficient way. Salting has been used to defend against dictionary attacks on one-way hash functions where an additional string is concatenated with a value to be encryptedÂ [32]. We adopt a similar concept in the SSS approach where the salting key is an additional random integer used by each party Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} individually when performing the secure summation. The salting key generated and used by each party is sent only to the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU and therefore a party Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}â€™s BF values cannot be identified by means of collusion among the parties, as without knowing the salting key of Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} its BF values cannot be learned. Since the salting keys are random integer values, performing secure summation of BFs with the salting keys does not add any additional computation and communication overhead, except the communication of salting keys from parties to the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU.

5 Communication patterns

In this section, we propose two variations of improved communication patterns for our protocol based on CBFs for multi-party scenarios with and without a linkage unit (Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU). The main idea of these improved communication patterns is to exploit the facts that most candidate sets are true non-matches (due to the class imbalance problem of record linkageÂ [3]), and that a true matching set must have a high similarity between any sub-set of records in that set. Hence for multi-party PPRL applications with many parties it is promising to determine partial matches for a sub-set of parties and consider additional parties only for these partial matches.

The parties are first arranged into rings of size rğ‘Ÿr (with râ‰¤pğ‘Ÿğ‘r\leq p) based on the value for the parameter rmsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šr_{m}, the minimum number of parties per ring (râ‰¥rmğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šr\geq r_{m}). The value of rmsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šr_{m} needs to be carefully chosen, as it has a trade-off between scalability (complexity) and privacy. The higher the value for rmsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šr_{m} is, the better the privacy of the protocol because the resulting CBFs are more difficult to exploit with an inference attack (by mapping the CBFs to known values in a global database to infer their underlying unencoded values), as will be discussed in SectionÂ 6.2. On the other hand, higher values of rmsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šr_{m} results in lower scalability to large datasets across many parties because the number of comparisons required per ring exponentially increases with the ring size rğ‘Ÿr.

5.1 Sequential communication

In this first proposed communication pattern (SEQ), which requires a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU, the matches found in one ring are compared with the candidate sets in the next ring resulting in a set of matches from both rings which will then be compared with the candidate sets in the following ring, and so on. This communication is carried out sequentially until the matches from all rings are found by the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU. FigureÂ 3 illustrates the SEQ approach for four rings with r=2ğ‘Ÿ2r=2 parties in each ring.

AlgorithmÂ 3 details the steps of the SEQ communication pattern. First the parties are grouped in rings using the function gâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹pâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘â‹…group(\cdot) (lineÂ 2 in AlgorithmÂ 3). Different number of parties (â‰¥rmabsentsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘š\geq r_{m}) can be grouped into different rings. The value for rmsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šr_{m} can be agreed upon by the parties to any value rmâ‰¥2subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘š2r_{m}\geq 2 at the trade-off between privacy and scalability, as will be discussed in SectionÂ 6.

To minimize the number of comparisons that are required, the grouping of parties into rings is ideally done in an ascending order of the size of their datasets. In this way, the first ring will generate a smaller number of matches, which then have to be compared with the candidate sets in the following rings. This reduces the computational complexity compared to initially larger number of matches being generated by the first ring if the parties in the first ring are the ones with the largest databases.

A loop is iterated over rings in lineÂ 3 of AlgorithmÂ 3 and then the parties in rings are iterated in lineÂ 4. Each party in râ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹gğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘”ring retrieves its records in lineÂ 5 and a loop is iterated over these records in lineÂ 7 to append each of them to every candidate record set (from previous party, except for the first party that appends to empty sets) stored in ğ‚ğ‚\mathbf{C} (lineÂ 8). Next, a secure summation protocol is applied in lineÂ 9 using sâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹_â€‹sâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘_ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šâ‹…sec\_sum(\cdot) function on the candidate sets of BFs ğ‚ğ‚\mathbf{C} identified in râ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹gğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘”ring in order to generate CBFs for each candidate set. In linesÂ 10-12, each CBF cğ‘c generated is then used to calculate the Dice similarity (Dâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹eâ€‹_â€‹sâ€‹iâ€‹mğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘’_ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘šDice\_sim) of the candidate set (câ€‹sğ‘ğ‘ cs) and if the Dâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹eâ€‹_â€‹sâ€‹iâ€‹mâ€‹(câ€‹s)â‰¥stğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘’_ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘ subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡Dice\_sim(cs)\geq s_{t} (lineÂ 13) then câ€‹sğ‘ğ‘ cs is added into the list of matches ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M} identified in the ring (lineÂ 14), which will then be used as an input (lineÂ 15) in the next ring.

The risk of collusion between parties in order to identify data about another party can be reduced in this approach by using different BF encodings in different iterations. For example, if the encoding used in ring 1 in FigureÂ 3 is unknown to parties in ring 2, then the collusion between the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU and parties in ring 2 would not reveal sufficient information to infer the actual values masked in the BFs in ring 1. Hence, parties might wish to be grouped with certain other parties in the same ring for better privacy protection.

5.2 Ring by ring communication

In the absence of a trusted Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU, as is required by the previously described SEQ communication approach, we propose a ring by ring communication pattern (RBR) for comparing CBFs from multiple parties without using a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU. This method is illustrated in FigureÂ 4 for three rings with r=3ğ‘Ÿ3r=3 parties in each ring, while AlgorithmÂ 4 outlines the steps of RBR in detail. Similar to SEQ, parties are grouped into rings using the gâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹pâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘â‹…group(\cdot) function (lineÂ 1 in AlgorithmÂ 4). The value for rmsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šr_{m} in RBR should be set to rmâ‰¥3subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘š3r_{m}\geq 3, as a minimum of three parties are required in each ring to perform secure summation without a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU.

The RBR method consists of two phases. In the first phase (linesÂ 2-14 in AlgorithmÂ 4), the parties in each ring (linesÂ 2-4) individually perform secure summation among them using sâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹_â€‹sâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘_ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šâ‹…sec\_sum(\cdot) (lineÂ 9) on their sets of candidate records ğ‚râ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹gsubscriptğ‚ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘”\mathbf{C}_{ring} (generated in linesÂ 5-8) to generate the CBFs ğ‚â€²râ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹gsubscriptsuperscriptğ‚â€²ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘”\mathbf{C^{\prime}}_{ring}, and calculate their similarities to identify matches ğŒrâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹gsubscriptğŒğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘”\mathbf{M}_{ring} in each ring (as shown in linesÂ 10-14). In the second phase in linesÂ 16-26, all parties then perform secure summation among them on the matches identified in each ring ğŒrâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹gsubscriptğŒğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘”\mathbf{M}_{ring} in order to identify matches ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M} from all pğ‘p parties.

Every ring in the first phase can employ a different set of BF parameters to reduce the possibility of collusion between a set of parties in different rings. In the second phase, all parties then have to agree on another set of parameters for BF encodings of the matches identified in rings in the first phase. In addition, the rings in the first phase can be processed independently and in parallel in a distributed environment making the RBR more scalable (than the SEQ) with larger dataset sizes.

6 Analysis of the protocol

In this section we analyze our multi-party PPRL protocol in terms of complexity, privacy, and linkage quality.

6.1 Complexity analysis

We assume pğ‘p parties participate in the protocol, each having a database of nğ‘›n records. We assume a private blocking/indexing technique employed in the blocking step forms bâ‰¤nğ‘ğ‘›b\leq n blocks for each party. In StepÂ 1 of our protocol, the agreement of parameters has a constant communication complexity. Blocking the databases in StepÂ 2 has Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) computation complexity at each party, and finding the intersection of blocks from all parties has a communication complexity of Oâ€‹(pâ‹…b)ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘ğ‘O(p\cdot b) and a computation complexity of Oâ€‹(bâ‹…lâ€‹oâ€‹gâ€‹b)ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”ğ‘O(b\cdot log~{}b) at each party, as pâ‹…bâ‹…ğ‘ğ‘p\cdot b BKVs need to be securely communicated, and for each of the bğ‘b BKVs a search operation of Oâ€‹(lâ€‹oâ€‹gâ€‹b)ğ‘‚ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”ğ‘O(log~{}b) is required in order to identify the intersection set. Assuming the average number of qğ‘q-grams in the QID attributes Ağ´A of each record is gğ‘”g, the masking of QID values of records into BFs of length lğ‘™l using kğ‘˜k hash functions for nğ‘›n records in StepÂ 3 is Oâ€‹(nâ‹…gâ‹…k)ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘›ğ‘”ğ‘˜O(n\cdot g\cdot k) at each party.

StepsÂ 4 andÂ 5 consist of the secure summation of BF vectors to calculate the CBFs of candidate sets. Our extended secure summation protocols HSS and SSS aim to improve privacy at the cost of complexity overhead. The extended HSS protocol requires nâ‹…lâ‹…pâ‹…ğ‘›ğ‘™ğ‘n\cdot l\cdot p encrypted values (long integers of 4 bytes each) to be exchanged among the parties, while the basic secure summation (BSS) and SSS require exchanging nâ‹…lâ‹…pâ‹…ğ‘›ğ‘™ğ‘n\cdot l\cdot p short integer values (of 2 bytes each), which is more efficient compared to HSS. Further, the homomorphic encryption and decryption functions used in HSS are computationally expensive compared to simple vector addition and subtraction operationsÂ [19].

With the simplified assumption that all blocks are of equal size n/bğ‘›ğ‘n/b, i.e. contain n/bğ‘›ğ‘n/b BFs at each party, then using the NAI communication method in each block (n/b)psuperscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘(n/b)^{p} candidate sets of BFs (i.e.Â all candidate sets of records in a block) have to be generated and their CBFs calculated. The first party performs bâ€‹(n/b)ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘b(n/b) summations, the second party bâ€‹(n/b)2ğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘2b(n/b)^{2}, and finally bâ€‹(n/b)pğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘b(n/b)^{p} summations are performed by the last party, leading to a total of Oâ€‹(âˆ‘i=1pbâ€‹(n/b)i)ğ‘‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘–O(\sum_{i=1}^{p}b(n/b)^{i}) summations in StepÂ 4.

In StepÂ 5, either the linkage unit Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU or the first party that initiated the secure summation protocol performs a vector subtraction operation (subtracts the random vectors from the summed vectors) on all the candidate sets, resulting in bâ€‹(n/b)pğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘b(n/b)^{p} CBFs. The similarities of these CBFs are then calculated and matches classified, which requires Oâ€‹(bâ€‹(n/b)p)ğ‘‚ğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘O(b(n/b)^{p}) computations. This combinatorial complexity currently limits the NAI linkage to a small number of parties or a large number of small blocks (i.e.Â pğ‘p or n/bğ‘›ğ‘n/b has to be small).

The communication patterns SEQ and RBR proposed in SectionsÂ 5.1 and 5.2, respectively, improve StepsÂ 4 andÂ 5 significantly (depending on the number of parties per ring, rğ‘Ÿr) by reducing the computation and communication complexities. In general the complexities are reduced from the exponential growth with pğ‘p down to r+1ğ‘Ÿ1r+1 in SEQ and mâ€‹aâ€‹xâ€‹(r,p/r)ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘Ÿmax(r,p/r) in RBR. With the simplified assumption that each ring has rğ‘Ÿr parties, the computation and communication complexities of the SEQ and RBR methods are as follows.

In the SEQ method, bâ€‹(n/b)rğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘Ÿb(n/b)^{r} candidate sets are processed in the first ring and bâ€‹(n/b)r+1ğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1b(n/b)^{r+1} in each of the remaining rings (i.e. bâ€‹(n/b)ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘b(n/b) matching sets, in the worst case, from the previous ring are compared with the bâ€‹(n/b)rğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘Ÿb(n/b)^{r} sets in each ring), resulting in total computation and communication complexities of O(âˆ‘i=1rb(n/b)iO(\sum_{i=1}^{r}b(n/b)^{i} + (âˆ‘i=1r+1bâ€‹(n/b)iâ‹…(p/râˆ’1))superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘Ÿ1â‹…ğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1(\sum_{i=1}^{r+1}b(n/b)^{i}\cdot(p/r-1)) (with r<pğ‘Ÿğ‘r<p). The computation and communication complexities of the RBR method is O(âˆ‘i=1rb(n/b)iâ‹…(p/r)O(\sum_{i=1}^{r}b(n/b)^{i}\cdot(p/r) + âˆ‘i=1p/rb(n/b)i)\sum_{i=1}^{p/r}b(n/b)^{i}), where the first phase requires bâ€‹(n/b)rğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘Ÿb(n/b)^{r} total candidate sets to be processed in each of the p/rğ‘ğ‘Ÿp/r rings and the second phase compares the bâ€‹(n/b)ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘b(n/b) matching sets from each ring.

Overall, the complexity of the NAI method is Oâ€‹(bâ€‹(n/b)p)ğ‘‚ğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘O(b(n/b)^{p}), the SEQ method is Oâ€‹(bâ€‹(n/b)r+1â‹…p/r)ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘ğ‘ŸO(b(n/b)^{r+1}\cdot p/r), and the RBR method is O(max(b(n/b)râ‹…p/r,b(n/b)p/r)O(max(b(n/b)^{r}\cdot p/r,b(n/b)^{p/r}). This theoretical analysis shows that the two proposed communication methods SEQ and RBR are computationally efficient compared to the NAI method. Depending on the values for pğ‘p and rğ‘Ÿr, the SEQ and RBR methods outperform each other.

The memory size required for a CBF is 2xsuperscript2ğ‘¥2^{x}, which is 2xâ‰¥psuperscript2ğ‘¥ğ‘2^{x}\geq p, bits for every position in the CBF. If the length of CBF is lğ‘™l, the total memory consumption is lÃ—âŒˆlâ€‹oâ€‹g2â€‹(p)âŒ‰ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘”2ğ‘l\times\lceil log_{2}(p)\rceil. For pğ‘p BFs the memory required is 111 bit for every position in the BF, and therefore the total memory consumption of 1Ã—lÃ—p1ğ‘™ğ‘1\times l\times p. CBF requires relatively more memory than using BFs when pğ‘p is small, however with increasing number of pğ‘p in multi-party PPRL, a CBF requires significantly lower memory compared to BFs. For example, when p=5ğ‘5p=5 and l=1,000ğ‘™1000l=1,000 the respective memory sizes of a CBF and corresponding BFs are 1000Ã—âŒˆlâ€‹oâ€‹g2â€‹(5)âŒ‰=30001000ğ‘™ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘”2530001000\times\lceil log_{2}(5)\rceil=3000 bits and 1Ã—1000Ã—5=500011000550001\times 1000\times 5=5000 bits, while for p=10ğ‘10p=10 and l=1,000ğ‘™1000l=1,000 they are 1000Ã—âŒˆlâ€‹oâ€‹g2â€‹(10)âŒ‰=40001000ğ‘™ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘”21040001000\times\lceil log_{2}(10)\rceil=4000 bits and 1Ã—1000Ã—10=100001100010100001\times 1000\times 10=10000 bits, respectively.

6.2 Privacy analysis

As with most of the existing PPRL approaches, we assume that all parties follow the honest-but-curious (semi-honest) adversary modelÂ [43], where the parties follow the protocol while being curious to learn the other partiesâ€™ data by means of inference attacks on input dataÂ [41] or collusionÂ [43]. To analyze the privacy against inference attacks, we discuss what the parties can learn through inference attacks or collusion during the protocol. We assume a trusted Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU is available, which does not collude with any parties, as is commonly used in many practical PPRL applicationsÂ [29].

However, collusion among the database owners is a privacy risk in the basic secure summation protocol where a set of parties can collude to learn the BF of another party using their received summation values. To overcome this problem, in SectionÂ 4 we have proposed two extended secure summation protocols, HSS and SSS. The HSS protocol uses homomorphic encryptions for secure summation which makes the protocol more secure because without knowing the private key (which is only known to the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU) identifying a partyâ€™s BF values by means of collusion will not be successful. However, this protocol encrypts each integer value in a BF (in total lğ‘™l values for each BF) into a hash key (long integers) and thus incurs a very large communication overhead making the protocol not viable for linkage of multiple large databases. The SSS protocol similarly makes the protocol more secure by adding additional integer values as salting keys by each party individually (known only to the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU) in the secure summation, such that without knowing the salting key value collusion among parties to learn a partyâ€™s BF is not possible. Compared to HSS, the SSS approach does not incur any expensive communication overhead as the salting keys are small integer values.

Communication occurs among the parties in StepÂ 1 of our protocol (as described in SectionÂ 3) where they agree on parameter settings, and in StepsÂ 4 andÂ 5 where they participate in a secure summation protocol. The agreement of parameter settings in StepÂ 1 does not reveal any sensitive information about the underlying data. Secure summation involves partial (masked) data exchange where the parties communicate the partial and full summations of their BFs (1) among them in StepÂ 4 and (2) to the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU or the first party that initiated the communication in StepÂ 5, respectively, to calculate the CBFs of the candidate sets and their similarities.

The Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU (in SEQ or NAI) or the first party in each ring (in RBR) receives the CBFs of candidate sets in each ring. Compared to calculating similarities of sets using their BFs directly, using a CBF makes the inference attack on individual BFs and thus their qğ‘q-grams (strings) mapped into them more difficult. An inference attack allows an adversary to map a list of known values from a global dataset (e.g.Â qğ‘q-grams or attribute values from a public telephone directory) to the encoded values (BFs or CBF) using background information (such as frequency)Â [41, 16]. The only information that can be learned from such an inference attack using a CBF cğ‘c of a set of xğ‘¥x BFs (summed over xğ‘¥x parties, where either x=pğ‘¥ğ‘x=p in NAI and RBR methods or x=rğ‘¥ğ‘Ÿx=r in SEQ and RBR methods) is if a bit position in cğ‘c is either 00 or xğ‘¥x which means it is set to 00 or 111, respectively, in the BFs from all xğ‘¥x parties.

Proposition 1.

The probability of identifying the original (unencoded) values of xğ‘¥x (x>1ğ‘¥1x>1) individual records Risubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–R_{i} (with 1â‰¤iâ‰¤x1ğ‘–ğ‘¥1\leq i\leq x) given a single CBF cğ‘c is smaller than the probability of identifying the original (unencoded values) of Risubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–R_{i} given xğ‘¥x individual BFs bisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–b_{i}, 1â‰¤iâ‰¤x1ğ‘–ğ‘¥1\leq i\leq x.

Hence, âˆ€i=1xPâ€‹râ€‹(Ri|c)<Pâ€‹râ€‹(Ri|bi)superscriptsubscriptfor-allğ‘–1ğ‘¥ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\forall_{i=1}^{x}Pr(R_{i}|c)<Pr(R_{i}|b_{i}).

We will empirically evaluate and compare the amount of privacy provided by masking records into CBFs and BFs against an inference attack in SectionÂ 7.5. A larger number of parties in a ring rğ‘Ÿr (i.e.Â the larger the value for xğ‘¥x) results in an increase in the difficulty of an inference attack (a smaller probability of suspicion 1/x1ğ‘¥1/x) by the adversary (Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU or the first party in each ring for SEQ and RBR, respectively) at the cost of more candidate set comparisons.

Further, using different hash encodings h1,â‹¯,hksubscriptâ„1â‹¯subscriptâ„ğ‘˜h_{1},\cdots,h_{k} by different rings in our SEQ and RBR methods improves privacy compared to the NAI method by reducing the possibilities of collusions, as discussed in SectionÂ 5. Since the hash functions used by parties in ringÂ 1, for example, are not known to parties in other rings, a collusion between parties in other rings and / or the Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU will not be successful in inferring the original values of parties in ringÂ 1. A careful grouping of parties is therefore required to improve privacy in a multi-party setting (for example, Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU randomly groups or changes the grouping for different blocks). More specifically, when pğ‘p parties are involved in the linkage, the maximum number of possible combinations for collusion in NAI method is âˆ‘i=1p(pâˆ’1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ‘1\sum_{i=1}^{p}(p-1), while in SEQ and RBR it is âˆ‘i=1p/râˆ‘j=1r(râˆ’1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ1\sum_{i=1}^{p/r}\sum_{j=1}^{r}(r-1). For example, with p=9ğ‘9p=9 parties the NAI method has 727272 possibilities to collude while grouping into equal sized rings (r=3ğ‘Ÿ3r=3) leads to only 181818 different collusion possibilities.

The values for the number of hash functions used (kğ‘˜k) and the length of the BF (lğ‘™l) provide a trade-off between the linkage quality and privacyÂ [34]. The higher the value for k/lğ‘˜ğ‘™k/l, the higher the privacy and the lower the quality of linkage, because the number of qğ‘q-grams mapped to a single bit (and therefore the number of resulting collisions) increases, which leads to lower linkage quality but makes it more difficult for an adversary to learn the possible qğ‘q-gram combinationsÂ [16]. The CLK encoding method (as discussed in SectionÂ 2.1) of hash-mapping several QID values from each record into one compound BFÂ [34, 38] makes it even more difficult for an adversary to learn individual QID values that correspond to a revealed bit pattern in a BF.

6.3 Linkage quality analysis

Our protocol supports approximate matching of QID values, in that data errors and variations are taken into account depending on the minimum similarity threshold stsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡s_{t} used. The quality of BF-based masking depends on the BF parameterizationÂ [34, 37]. For a given BF length, lğ‘™l, and the number of elements gğ‘”g (e.g. qğ‘q-grams) to be inserted into the BF, the optimal number of hash functions, kğ‘˜k, that minimizes the false positive rate fğ‘“f (of a collision of two different qğ‘q-grams being mapped to the same bit position), is calculated asÂ [21] k=l/gâ€‹lâ€‹nâ€‹(2)ğ‘˜ğ‘™ğ‘”ğ‘™ğ‘›2k=l/g~{}ln(2), leading to a false positive rate of f=(1/2lâ€‹nâ€‹(2))l/gğ‘“superscript1superscript2ğ‘™ğ‘›2ğ‘™ğ‘”f=(1/2^{ln(2)})^{l/g}.

While kğ‘˜k and lğ‘™l determine the computational aspects of BF masking, linkage quality and privacy will be determined by the false positive rate fğ‘“f. A higher value for fğ‘“f will mean a larger number of false matches and thus lower linkage qualityÂ [21, 34]. In our experimental evaluation we will set the BF parameters for our approach according to the discussion presented here and following earlier BF work in PPRLÂ [9, 34, 38, 37].

7 Experimental evaluation

In this section, we empirically evaluate the performance of our protocol (which we refer as AM-CBF for Approximate Matching with Counting BFs) with the SEQ, RBR, and NAI communication patterns in terms of the three properties of PPRL, scalability (complexity), linkage quality, and privacy. We describe the competing baseline methods in SectionÂ 7.1, the datasets used in SectionÂ 7.2, the evaluation measures in SectionÂ 7.3, and the experimental settings in SectionÂ 7.4. We then discuss the experimental results in SectionÂ 7.5.

7.1 Baseline methods

We use Lai et al.Â [17]â€™s exact matching BF-based PPRL approach (referred as EM-BF for Exact Matching with BFs) and Vatsalan and ChristenÂ [39, 40]â€™s approximate matching BF-based PPRL approach (AM-BF for Approximate Matching with BFs) as competing baseline methods to compare with our proposed approach. Since other existing approaches for multi-party PPRL (as reviewed in SectionÂ 8) are either based on expensive cryptographic techniques or applicable to categorical data only, we do not compare them with our approach.

Lai et al.â€™s EM-BF approachÂ [17] performs exact matching of QIDs across multiple parties using BFs. In their approach, the QID values of all records in a dataset are first converted into one BF. Each party then partitions its BF into segments according to the number of parties involved in the linkage, and sends these segments to the corresponding other parties. The segments received by a party are combined using a conjunction (logical AND) operation. The resulting conjuncted BF segments are then exchanged between the parties to construct the full conjuncted BF. Each party checks its own full BF of each record with the conjuncted BF, and if the membership test is successful then the record is considered to be a match. Though the cost of this approach is low since the computation is completely distributed between the parties and the processing of BFs is fast, the approach can only perform exact matching.

Vatsalan and Christen proposed AM-BFÂ [39, 40] by adapting the idea used in EM-BF of distributively computing the conjunction of a set of BFs from multiple parties to perform privacy-preserving approximate matching for multi-party PPRL. Once the conjuncted BF segments are computed by the respective parties, a secure summation protocol is initiated among the parties to securely sum the number of common 111-bits in the conjuncted BF segments as well as the total number of 111-bits in each partyâ€™s BF. These two sums are then used to calculate the Dice coefficient similarity of the set of BFs. A filtering approach is employed to reduce the number of comparisons based on segment similarity, such that if a sub-set of BF segments of a candidate set (as calculated by a respective party) has lower similarity then the BFs do not have to be compared with any of the BFs from the other parties.

Both EM-BF and AM-BF approaches use the NAI method for comparing and classifying candidate sets of records.

7.2 Datasets

To provide a realistic evaluation of our approach, we based all our experiments on a large real-world database, the North Carolina Voter Registration (NCVR) database as available from ftp://alt.ncsbe.gov/data/. This database has been used for the evaluation of various other PPRL approachesÂ [9, 26, 27, 39, 40, 41]. We have downloaded this database every second month since October 2011 and built a combined temporal dataset that contains over 8 million records of votersâ€™ names and addressesÂ [4]. We are not aware of any available real-world dataset that contains records from more than two parties that would allow us to evaluate multi-party PPRL approaches. We therefore generated, based on the real NCVR database, a series of sub-sets for multiple parties, as will be described next.

To allow the evaluation of our approach with different number of parties, with different dataset sizes, and with data of different quality, we used and modified a recently proposed data corruptorÂ [5, 36] to generate various datasets with different characteristics based on randomly selected records from the NCVR database. The identifiers of the selected and modified records were kept the same, which allows us to identify true and false matches and therefore evaluate linkage quality, as described below. Specifically, we extracted sub-sets of 5,00050005,000, 10,0001000010,000, 50,0005000050,000, 100,000100000100,000, 500,000500000500,000, and 1,000,00010000001,000,000 records from the NCVR to generate datasets for 333, 555, 777, and 101010 parties, where the number of matching records is set to 50% (i.e.Â half of selected records occur in the datasets of all parties).

To evaluate how the approaches work with â€˜dirtyâ€™ data, we created several series of datasets for each of the datasets generated above, where we included a varying number of corrupted records into the sets of overlapping records (0%percent00\%, 20%percent2020\%, and 40%percent4040\%). We applied various corruption functions on randomly selected attribute values, including character edit operations (insertions, deletions, substitutions, and transpositions), and optical character recognition and phonetic modifications based on look-up tables and corruption rulesÂ [5]. This means that a certain percentage of records in the overlap were modified for randomly selected parties, while the original values were kept for the other parties. Therefore, some of these records are exact duplicates across some parties in a set, but are only approximately matching duplicates across the other parties in the set. This simulates, for example, the situation where three out of five hospitals have the correct and complete contact details (like name and address) of a certain patient, while in the fourth and fifth hospitals some of the details of the same patient are different.

7.3 Evaluation measures

We evaluate the three properties of PPRL using the following evaluation measures. The complexity (scalability) of linkage is measured by runtime, communication size, and the number of comparisons required for the linkage. The quality of the achieved linkage is measured using the F-measure, calculated on classified matches and non-matches, that has widely been used in record linkage, information retrieval and data miningÂ [2].

In line with other work in PPRLÂ [26, 39, 40, 41], we evaluate privacy using disclosure risk (DR) measures based on the probability of suspicion, i.e.Â the likelihood a masked (encoded) database record in ğƒMsuperscriptğƒğ‘€\mathbf{D}^{M} can be matched with one or several (masked) record(s) in a publicly available global database ğ†ğ†\mathbf{G}. The probability of suspicion for a masked value/record RMsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘€R^{M}, Pâ€‹râ€‹(RM)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘€Pr(R^{M}), is calculated as 1/ng1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘”1/n_{g} where ngsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘”n_{g} is the number of possible matches in ğ†Msuperscriptğ†ğ‘€\mathbf{G}^{M} to the masked value RMsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘€R^{M}. We conducted a frequency linkage attackÂ [41] by mapping the exchanged bit information in the BFs generated from ğƒMsuperscriptğƒğ‘€\mathbf{D}^{M} to the BFs generated from ğ†Msuperscriptğ†ğ‘€\mathbf{G}^{M}. We used the worst case scenario where ğ†â‰¡ğƒğ†ğƒ\mathbf{G}\equiv\mathbf{D}, because when ğ†â‰¡ğƒğ†ğƒ\mathbf{G}\equiv\mathbf{D} there will be a one-to-one exact matching of a global value for each value in ğƒğƒ\mathbf{D}. Based on such linkage attack, we calculate the following disclosure risk measures, as proposed by Vatsalan et al.Â [41].

  • â€¢

    Mean disclosure risk (Dâ€‹RMâ€‹eâ€‹aâ€‹nğ·subscriptğ‘…ğ‘€ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘›DR_{Mean}): This calculates the average risk (âˆ‘i|ğƒM|superscriptsubscriptğ‘–superscriptğƒğ‘€\sum_{i}^{|\mathbf{D}^{M}|} Pâ€‹râ€‹(RiM)/|ğƒM|ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘€superscriptğƒğ‘€Pr(R_{i}^{M})/|\mathbf{D}^{M}|) of any sensitive value in ğƒMsuperscriptğƒğ‘€\mathbf{D}^{M} being re-identified.

  • â€¢

    Marketer disclosure risk (Dâ€‹RMâ€‹aâ€‹râ€‹kğ·subscriptğ‘…ğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜DR_{Mark}): This is calculated as the proportion of masked records in ğƒMsuperscriptğƒğ‘€\mathbf{D}^{M} that match to exactly one masked record in ğ†Msuperscriptğ†ğ‘€\mathbf{G}^{M} (|{RMâˆˆğƒM:Pâ€‹râ€‹(RM)=1.0}|/|ğƒM|conditional-setsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘€superscriptğƒğ‘€ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘€1.0superscriptğƒğ‘€|\{R^{M}\in\mathbf{D}^{M}:Pr(R^{M})=1.0\}|/|\mathbf{D}^{M}|).

7.4 Experimental settings

We implemented both our proposed approach and the competing baseline approaches in Python 2.7.3, and ran all experiments on a server with four 6-core 64-bit Intel Xeon 2.4 GHz CPUs, 128 GBytes of memory and running Ubuntu 14.04. The programs and test datasets are available from the authors.

Following the discussion in SectionÂ 6.3 and other work in PPRLÂ [9, 33, 38], we set the parameters as BF length l=500ğ‘™500l=500, the number of hash functions k=20ğ‘˜20k=20, the length of grams q=2ğ‘2q=2, the minimum similarity threshold st=0.8subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡0.8s_{t}=0.8, and the number of parties p=[3,5,7,10]ğ‘35710p=[3,5,7,10]. For the SEQ method the minimum number of parties per ring was set to rm=2subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘š2r_{m}=2 and for the RBR method rm=3subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘š3r_{m}=3. The attributes first name, last name, city, and zipcode were used as the QIDs in the linkage. We applied a Soundex-based phonetic blockingÂ [2] for the private blocking step in all approaches, which results in a set of blocks on which we individually conduct private comparison and classification.

The experiments are two-fold. In the first part we evaluate the scalability of our approach with proposed communication patterns and compare with the NAI method. In the second part we compare the complexity, linkage quality, and privacy of our approach (with the SEQ approach as it gave the best results in the first part) with baseline methods. We used the first name and last name attributes as the blocking keys in the second set of experiments and all four attributes in the first set of scalability experiments in order to allow for comparative evaluation with the NAI method (as we were unable to run experiments for the NAI method on larger datasets with larger pğ‘p when only two blocking attributes were used).

7.5 Discussion

TableÂ 1 shows the runtime and memory size required and the F-measure results achieved with the three secure summation protocols. As can be seen, the HSS requires significantly higher runtime and memory (which is not practical in real applications) to improve privacy against collusion attacks on the BSS without compromising the F-measure results. However, the SSS approach requires similar runtime and memory as the BSS for improving privacy against collusions with no loss in linkage quality. We therefore use SSS in all following experiments.

FiguresÂ 5 (a) and (b) show the complexity of our AM-CBF approach with the proposed communication patterns SEQ and RBR in terms of runtime and communication size (comm), while FigureÂ 5 (c) shows the runtime and communication size required by the NAI communication pattern. As the figures show the proposed communication methods improve the scalability of our multi-party approach by significantly reducing the number of candidate sets (and thereby the complexities) compared to the NAI method (which has been used in many existing solutions including the baseline approaches). As discussed in SectionÂ 6.1, SEQ is faster than RBR (FigureÂ 5 (a)). When p=5ğ‘5p=5, RBR is equivalent to NAI (as we set rm=3subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘š3r_{m}=3). Both SEQ and RBR are scalable (almost linear) with the dataset size and the number of parties compared to the NAI method that increases exponentially with the number of datasets and their sizes. We were unable to conduct linkage experiments using the NAI method for larger pğ‘p and dataset sizes due to its exponential complexity (and thus some data points for the NAI method are missing in FigureÂ 5 (c)).

FigureÂ 5 (d) shows the number of candidate sets to be compared and classified using our AM-CBF approach. The number of candidate sets with the NAI method grows exponentially with the size of the datasets for increasing pğ‘p, as can be seen when p=10ğ‘10p=10. In FiguresÂ 5 (e) and (f), we compare the complexity requirements of the SEQ and RBR methods with different ring sizes based on rmsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šr_{m} on the NCVR-10,000 datasets for p=10ğ‘10p=10 parties. We evaluated the SEQ method with rm=[2,3,4,5]subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘š2345r_{m}=[2,3,4,5] and the RBR method with rm=[3,4,5]subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘š345r_{m}=[3,4,5] (rmâ‰¥3subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘š3r_{m}\geq 3 in RBR). This provides ring sizes of [2,2,2,2,2], [3,3,4], [4,6], and [5,5] for rm=2subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘š2r_{m}=2, 333, 444, and 555, respectively. As shown in the figures, the complexity increases with larger ring sizes, because larger ring sizes mean more comparisons are required in each ring.

We compare the runtime required by our approach (with SEQ) with the baseline approaches on the NCVR-10,000 and 50,000 datasets in FigureÂ 6 (a). Though the baseline approaches require lower runtime for linking pâ‰¤5ğ‘5p\leq 5 datasets than our approach (because the matches identified in one ring need to be compared again with the candidate sets in the other rings in our approach), they are not scalable to more parties (p>5ğ‘5p>5) and larger datasets. We were unable to conduct experiments for AM-BF with p>7ğ‘7p>7 and EM-BF with p>5ğ‘5p>5 on the NCVR-50,000 datasets due to the exponential increase in the number of candidate sets generated. As can be seen in FigureÂ 6 (a), our approach is scalable and requires significantly lower runtime for linking p=7ğ‘7p=7 and 101010 datasets compared to the baseline approaches.

As shown in FigureÂ 6 (b), our approach outperforms the baseline EM-BF and AM-BF approaches in terms of linkage quality measured by F-measure. The filtering approach used in AM-BF results in lower F-measure compared to our approach. The F-measure is high on the non-modified datasets (0% corruption), while it drops with pğ‘p on the modified (20% and 40%) datasets as the number of missed true matches increases when records are modified in each dataset. However, our AM-CBF approach achieves the highest F-measure on both modified and non-modified datasets (though EM-BF performs equally well on the non-modified datasets).

Finally, we compared the DR measures of privacy for our approach based on CBF masking with baseline approaches based on BF masking in FiguresÂ 6 (c) and (d). The results show that the DR measures with our approach are consistently lower (and thus privacy is higher) than the baseline approaches. As expected, the DR measures also decrease with larger pğ‘p (as discussed in SectionÂ 6.2), and with more corruptions in the dataset because corrupted records reduce the probability of mapping to matching global values in ğ†ğ†\mathbf{G} to allow the records to be re-identified.

8 Related Work

Various techniques have been proposed in the literature tackling the problem of PPRLÂ [43]. However, most of them consider linking two databases only, and a only few approaches have been proposed for PPRL on multiple databases.

An SMC-based approach using an oblivious transfer protocol was proposed by Oâ€™Keefe et al.Â [23] for PPRL on multiple databases. While provably secure, the approach only performs exact matching of masked values (i.e.Â variations and errors in the QIDs are not considered) and it is computationally expensive compared to efficient perturbation-based privacy techniques, such as BFs and kğ‘˜k-anonymityÂ [43]. A multi-party kğ‘˜k-anonymity-based PPRL approach was introduced by Kantarcioglu et al.Â [12]. In their apporach, a secure equi-join (exact matching) is applied on the kğ‘˜k-anonymized databases by a Lâ€‹Uğ¿ğ‘ˆLU to identify matching records.

A multi-party PPRL approach for approximate matching of categorical values was proposed by Mohammed et al.Â [22], where a top-down generalization is performed to provide kğ‘˜k-anonymous privacy and the generalized blocks are then classified into matches and non-matches using the C4.5 decision tree classifier. Another efficient multi-party approach for categorical data was recently proposed by Karapiperis et al.Â [14] using a Count-Min sketch data structure. Sketches are used to summarize the local set of elements which are then intersected to provide a global synopsis using homomorphic operations, secure summation, and symmetric noise addition privacy techniques.

As described in SectionÂ 7.1, Lai et al.Â [17]â€™s approach uses efficient Bloom filter encoding for masking string data in multi-party PPRL. However, the approach performs only exact matching. This approach has been adapted by Vatsalan and ChristenÂ [39, 40] for approximate matching in multi-party PPRL (as described in detail in SectionÂ 7.1). Several approximate comparison functions for calculating similarities of pairs of string and other data types have been proposed for PPRL by adapting existing comparison functions.

A secure version of the Levenshtein edit distance was proposed by Karakasidis and VerykiosÂ [13] using CBFs, where the elements of a string are checked against a CBF of another string to count the number of edits, while the CBF also provides the length of the string masked into it. However, developing privacy-preserving comparison functions for multiple (more than two) values has only recently been considered by Vatsalan and ChristenÂ [39, 40] using the Dice coefficient similarity.

Scalability has been addressed by using private blocking functions and / or filtering approachesÂ [43, 44] as well as by parallelizing and / or distributing the tasks among several nodes or partiesÂ [15, 44]. The scalability problem in multi-party PPRL has only recently been focused on. Ranbaduge et al.Â [27, 28] proposed a family of efficient tree-based private blocking techniques for multi-party PPRL using BF encoding and secure summation. Several filtering approaches have been used in PPRL of two sources, including length filtering in BFsÂ [38] and PPJoin techniquesÂ [35]. The recently proposed multi-party BF-based PPRL approachÂ [39, 40] (described above) employs a filtering approach based on the similarity of segments of BFs. However, the number of comparisons required for multi-party linkage remains very large even with existing private blocking and filtering approaches employedÂ [27, 39]. Therefore, efficient multi-party filtering and communication patterns need to be developed in order to make PPRL scalable and viable in practical applications.

Several query tree representations have been used for optimizing multi-way join queriesÂ [20, 31]. Schneider and DeWittÂ [31] studied query processing plans with different types of structures, left-deep, right-deep, and bushy. Left-deep and right-deep trees use a base table as the inner and outer operand, respectively, of each join in the plan, while in bushy trees both inputs to a join may themselves result from joins. However, these techniques have not been used for efficient processing of multi-party PPRL.

9 Conclusion

We have presented an efficient and scalable protocol for PPRL of multiple databases with two improved communication patterns. Our approach performs approximate matching on the QID values (of string data) masked using efficient and simple privacy techniques, counting BFs and secure summation. Experiments conducted on real datasets showed the efficiency and scalability of our approach compared to two baseline approaches while achieving superior results in terms of linkage quality and privacy.

In future work, we plan to investigate other improved communication patterns, collision resistant secure summation protocols, and different approximate string comparison functionsÂ [2] to be incorporated. We also aim to develop efficient PPRL techniques for identifying matching record sets within sub-sets of parties, which is an important research problem.

Another research direction would be to develop multi-party PPRL approaches under other adversary models such as the covert modelÂ [1] or accountable computingÂ [11] (where honest parties can verify fake data from dishonest parties with high probability) to overcome the limitations of the semi-honest (HBC) adversary model. Finally, we plan to investigate improved classification techniques for multi-party PPRL including relational clustering and graph-based approachesÂ [2] which are successfully used in non-PPRL applications.
